Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a TIMS for Expanding Applications at the University of Houston
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF funds will be used to acquire a thermal ionization mass spectrometer (TIMS) for the measurement of isotope ratios of elements. The isotope ratios acquired with the TIMS will be used to understand elemental cycles in the interior of the Earth and on its surface. The TIMS will be part of a Core Facility that will enable opportunities for researchers in the greater Texas Gulf region, and will foster collaborations with scientists outside of this region as well as internationally. The TIMS Core Facility has a strong history of serving students, post-docs, and faculty from diverse backgrounds and ethnicities. The work performed on the new TIMS will thus further undergraduate and graduate research in geochemistry and archeology involving women and underrepresented groups that will lead to successful outcomes for pursuing STEM careers.

The TIMS will advance research and training in chemical petrology, isotope geochemistry and archeology. Isotope ratios from a broad spectrum of elements will be measured on a wide variety of materials to provide tracers for geological processes, ages of Earth materials, and for determining the histories of ancient human societies. Important questions that will be addressed with these data include: (1) how the Earth's mantle melts and how these melts subsequently react with the mantle as they migrate to the surface; (2) the timing of black shale formation in sedimentary basins; (3) the chemical evolution of seawater and how it relates to global climate changes in the past; (4) the origin of the Younger Dryas mass extinction at 12,800 years ago; and (5) constraining the Holocene demographic transformations in human societies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to purchase and bring into operation a Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer (TIMS). This TIMS will be used to measure isotope ratios of elements relevant for solving problems in the geological sciences.  The instrument was delivered in the Spring of 2019. The activities included installing the instrument and making it operational. Installation occurred throughout the summer of 2019. In the Fall of 2019 the new TIMS became fully operational.  The new TIMS further builds up the strong instrument facilities at the University of Houston in geochemical and geological sciences. The new techniques developed will be used to integrate into studies that take advantage of all of the instrument facilities present.

In the first year of operation, development of new measurement techniques has been the primary focus.  This was performed by the principal investigator, a post-doctoral researcher, and a PhD student.  This allowed the post-doc and the graduate student to gain valuable professional development.  Many additional opportunities for training and professional development will occur throughout the following months and years for undergraduate and graduate students, post-docs, and PhD scientists.

With the new techniques developed on the TIMS, examples of where we are now applying them includes understanding how continents formed and evolved, how magmas and made and change as they cool, what the compositions of the materials were that formed the Earth, constraining what role volcanism has played in major climatic events in the geological past, and how surface sedimentary depositional environments are made. Because biological cycles on Earth are intimately embedded with dynamic cycles in and on Earth, the study of geological materials that will occur with this new TIMS will ultimately contribute a better understanding to Earth's dynamic cycles and their bearing on our biosphere.
